case_name: M/s. Balwant Singh Santok Singh v. Income-tax Officer

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 was the Income-tax Officer for Additional B-X VIII District, New Delhi between June 16, 1962, and May 4, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: Between June 16, 1962, and May 4, 1964, respondent No. 1 was the Income-tax Officer for Additional B-X VIII District, New Delhi.

facts.text: The appellants have been carrying on business in partnership in the name of M s. Balwant Singh Santok Singh within the said Additional B-VIII Income-tax District at all material times.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants have, at all material times, been carrying on business in partnership in the name of M s. Balwant Singh Santok Singh within the said Additional B-VIII  Income-tax  District.

facts.text: For the assessment year 1960-61 accounting year 1959-60, the firm was registered under section 26A of the Income-tax Act, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year 1960-61  accounting year 1959-60 , the firm was registered under section 26A of the Income-tax Act, 1922.

facts.text: During the assessment proceedings for the assessment year 1961-62 accounting year 1960-61, respondent No. 1 noticed that the firm had not applied for renewal of registration.

anchor.surface_text: During the assessment proceedings for the assessment year 1961-62  accounting year 1960-61 , respondent No. 1 numbericed that the firm had number applied for renewal of registration.

facts.text: The firm was liable to be assessed as an unregistered firm due to no renewal application.

anchor.surface_text: The firm was, therefore, liable to be assessed as an unregistered firm.

facts.text: Appellant No. 1, Balwant Singh, represented to respondent No. 1 that the firm had filed an application for renewal for the assessment year 1961-62 within the prescribed period.

anchor.surface_text: At that stage, appellant No. 1, Balwant Singh, represented to respondent No. 1 that the firm had filed an application for renewal for the assessment year 1961-62 within the prescribed period, and therefore, its registration should be renewed.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 adjourned the case to May 27, 1963, and called upon appellant No. 1 to produce evidence.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 1 adjourned the case to May 27, 1963, and called upon appellant No. 1 to produce evidence to show that such an application was made.

facts.text: On May 27, 1963, appellant No. 1 appeared before respondent No. 1.

anchor.surface_text: On May 27, 1963, appellant No. 1 appeared before respondent No. 1 and produced a certificate of posting dated June 21, 1961,

facts.text: Appellant No. 1 produced a certificate of posting dated June 21, 1961, purporting to prove the application was posted.

anchor.surface_text: produced a certificate of posting dated June 21, 1961, purporting to have been issued by the post office in proof of the application having been posted and also a duplicate application dated June 15, 1961,

facts.text: Appellant No. 1 produced a duplicate application dated June 15, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: and also a duplicate application dated June 15, 1961, said to have been posted and in respect whereof the certificate of posting was said to have been issued to the firm.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 noticed that the form of the certificate said to have been issued on June 21, 1961, was actually printed in 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 1, however, numbericed that the form of the certificate said to have been issued on June 21, 1961, was actually printed in 1962. This aroused his suspicion about the genuineness of the certificate.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 recorded the statement of appellant No. 1 on oath.

anchor.surface_text: He, therefore, recorded the statement of appellant No. 1 on oath.

facts.text: In the statement on oath, Appellant No. 1 asserted that the certificate was genuine, that his firm had posted the original application dated June 15, 1961, on June 21, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: In that statement, Appellant No. 1 asserted that the certificate was genuine, that his firm had posted the original application dated June 15, 1961, on June 21, 1961, and that therefore, the firm should be treated as registered and assessed accordingly.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 rejected the appellants' claim for renewal and assessed the firm as an unregistered firm.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 1 rejected the appellants claim for renewal and assessed the firm on the footing of an unregistered firm.

facts.text: In his assessment order passed on May 27, 1963, respondent No. 1 held that the appellants had fabricated the two documents and used them as genuine knowing them to be false and that appellant No. 1 had given false evidence on oath.

anchor.surface_text: In his assessment order passed on that very day he held that the appellants had fabricated the two documents and used them as genuine knowing them to be false and that appellant No. 1 had given false evidence on oath before him.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 did not pass an order in the assessment order that they should be prosecuted.

anchor.surface_text: But he did number pass an order in the said assessment order that they should be prosecuted.

facts.text: At the foot of the assessment order, there was a separate note to the effect that the appellants should be prosecuted.

anchor.surface_text: At the foot of the order, however, there was a separate numbere to the effect that the appellants should be prosecuted.

facts.text: On October 26, 1964, after respondent No. 1 ceased to be the Income-tax Officer, he lodged a complaint before the Magistrate.

anchor.surface_text: On October 26, 1964 i.e., after respondent No. 1 was said to have ceased to be the Income-tax Officer of the Additional B-XVIII District, he lodged a companyplaint before the Magistrate

facts.text: The complaint alleged that the certificate of posting and duplicate application were produced as genuine knowing them to be forged, and the statement on oath was false, liable for offences under sections 193 and 196 of the Penal Code.

anchor.surface_text: alleging that the said certificate of posting and the said duplicate application in the proceedings before him under section 26A of the Income-tax Act as genuine knowing them to be forged, that the statement on oath of appellant No. 1 was false

facts.text: The appellants filed an application before the High Court of Punjab Circuit Bench, New Delhi under section 561A of the Code of Criminal Procedure for quashing the complaint.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants filed an application before the High Court of Punjab  Circuit Bench, New Delhi  under section 561A of the Code of Criminal Procedure for quashing the said companyplaint.

facts.text: The High Court rejected the application.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court reject the application.

facts.text: The appellants obtained special leave from this court and filed this appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants obtained special leave from this companyrt and filed this appeal.

facts.text: Two contentions were urged before the High Court and before the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Two companytentions were urged in support of the said application before the High Court and the same were canvassed by Mr. Gupte before us.

facts.text: First contention: Income-tax Officer while acting under section 26A is a court and must follow procedure in sections 476 and 479A CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: 1  that the Income-tax Officer while acting under section 26A of the Income-tax Act, 1922, was a companyrt and that that being so, it was incumbent on him follow the procedure laid down in sections 476 and 479A of the Code of Criminal Procedure,

facts.text: Second contention: Respondent No. 1 had ceased to hold the charge of the post on the date of filing the complaint, so no jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: 2  that in any event, respondent No. 1 had ceased to hold the charge of the post of Income-tax Officer for Additional B-XVIII District, on the date of the filing of the said companyplaint and, therefore, the companyplaint was filed without jurisdiction

facts.text: Supreme Court held that proceedings under section 26A before respondent No. 1 are judicial proceedings in a court for purposes of section 195(1)(b) CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: That being the position, the proceedings under section 26A before respondent No. 1 must be treated as proceedings in companyrt for the purposes of section 195  1   b  of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer is not a revenue court.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer, however, cannot be treated as a revenue companyrt.

facts.text: Sections 476 and 479A do not apply to Income-tax Officer.

anchor.surface_text: Though, therefore, proceedings before the Income-tax Officer are judicial proceedings in a companyrt and section 195  1   b  applies, neither section 476 number section 479A of the Code would be applicable.

facts.text: It was not incumbent upon respondent No. 1 to follow procedure in sections 476 or 479A.

anchor.surface_text: It was, therefore, number incumbent upon respondent No. 1 to follow the procedure laid down in either of these two sections.

facts.text: Second contention is a question of evidence to be raised before the Magistrate.

anchor.surface_text: As regards his second companytention, the question raised by him would be one of evidence... The question being one of evidence the appellant can raise it before the Magistrate trying the companyplaint.

issues.text: whether the Income-tax Officer while acting under section 26A of the Income-tax Act, 1922, was a court and, that being so, it was incumbent on him to follow the procedure laid down in sections 476 and 479A of the Code of Criminal Procedure before he could validly file a complaint for offences under sections 193 and 196 of the Penal Code

anchor.surface_text: These were (1) that the Income-tax Officer while acting under section 26A of the Income-tax Act, 1922, was a court and that that being so, it was incumbent on him follow the procedure laid down in sections 476 and 479A of the Code of Criminal Procedure, before he could validly file a complaint for offences under sections 193 and 196 of the Penal Code, and

issues.text: whether in any event, respondent No. 1 had ceased to hold the charge of the post of Income-tax Officer for Additional B-XVIII District, on the date of the filing of the said complaint and, therefore, the complaint was filed without jurisdiction and the Magistrate could not take cognizance of such an illegal complaint

anchor.surface_text: and (2) that in any event, respondent No. 1 had ceased to hold the charge of the post of Income-tax Officer for Additional B-XVIII District, on the date of the filing of the said complaint and, therefore, the complaint was filed without jurisdiction and the Magistrate could not take cognizance of such an illegal complaint. Before we proceed further,

issues.text: whether section 476, or section 479A of the Code applies to the instant complaint

anchor.surface_text: The question, therefore, is whether section 476, or section 479A of the Code applies to the instant complaint. It will be observed that whereas section 195 uses the expression court sections 476 and 479A use the expression any civil, revenue or criminal court.

issues.text: whether the Income-tax Officer can be treated as a revenue court

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer, however, cannot be treated as a revenue court. Though, therefore, proceedings before the Income-tax Officer are judicial proceedings in a court and section 195(1) b applies, neither section 476 nor section 479A of the Code would be applicable.

Section 37 deems proceedings before ITO as judicial for IPC Sections 193, 196, 228, supporting the holding to treat Section 26A proceedings as court proceedings for CrPC Section 195(1)(b), which pertains to those IPC offences.
The limited deeming of ITO proceedings as judicial only for specific IPC sections under Section 37 supports the holding that CrPC Sections 476 and 479A procedures do not apply.
